response_parsed.title: Documenting Batch Jobs Using FastAPI with Python 3.12+
response_parsed.summary: This explainer provides a step-by-step guide on how to document batch jobs using the FastAPI framework in Python 3.12+. It covers creating APIs, writing documentation, and handling asynchronous tasks.

key_points.description: To get started, you'll need to install FastAPI and Uvicorn. You can do this using pip.
Write a Python script with the FastAPI base class as its starting point. This creates a new FastAPI application.

key_points.point: Define an asynchronous function for your batch job
key_points.description: Create an async function that represents your batch job. This function should perform the necessary tasks and return the result when complete.

key_points.point: Add a FastAPI route for your batch job
key_points.description: Define a new endpoint in your application using the FastAPI `@app.post` decorator. This route will trigger the asynchronous function.
Annotate your functions and routes with informative comments to provide clear documentation for other developers.
FastAPI provides support for handling asynchronous tasks. You can use the `Response` class to return a response with information about the batch job's status and expected completion time.
FastAPI offers the ability to run background tasks using the `BackgroundTasks` object. This can help manage long-running jobs more efficiently.

code_examples.code:
from fastapi import FastAPI, BackgroundTasks
app = FastAPI()
async def batch_job(bg_tasks: BackgroundTasks):
    # Your asynchronous code here

@app.post('/batch_job')
asynchronous def start_batch_job():
    bg_tasks.add_task(batch_job)
    return {'status': 'started'}

version_notes: This explainer focuses on FastAPI version 0.71.0, which is compatible with Python 3.12+
caveats: Ensure that you handle errors and edge cases appropriately to ensure the robustness of your batch job API.
